headline: Rosemary Braised Lamb Shanks
description: Incredibly tender lamb shanks braised in a rich red wine sauce with rosemary, thyme, garlic, and tomatoes is a dish that's guaranteed to impress.

video.description: Lamb shanks are slow-simmered in a flavorful red wine sauce.
video.name: Rosemary Braised Lamb Shanks

name: Rosemary Braised Lamb Shanks
recipeIngredient: 3 large carrots, cut into 1/4 inch rounds
1 (28 ounce) can whole peeled tomatoes with juice

recipeInstructions.text: Season lamb shanks with salt and pepper.
Heat oil in a large, heavy pot or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Working in batches, cook shanks until brown on all sides, about 8 minutes. Transfer shanks to a plate; set aside.
Add carrots, onions, and garlic to the pot and sauté over medium heat until golden brown, about 10 minutes. Stir in wine, tomatoes, chicken broth, beef broth, rosemary, and thyme.
Return shanks to the pot, pressing down to submerge. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to medium-low. Cover and simmer until meat is tender, about 2 hours.

Remove the lid and simmer to allow flavors to concentrate, about 20 minutes. Transfer shanks to a platter; cover with foil to keep warm. Continue boiling sauce until thickened, about 15 minutes. Spoon sauce over shanks before serving.

review.reviewBody: Good flavor. Hope it is better on day 2. From the other comments, it seems like the size of lamb shanks vary. I made four instead of six and adjusted the liquids accordingly. I also added a corn starch slurry, and that helped a lot, in addition to cooking down the sauce. What I will definitely do next time is use a spice pouch or bag so that I don't have to strain the sauce at all. Last thing added was some orange zest to brighten up the sauce at the end. Thank you for a great recipe!
Restaurant quality!! Everyone was blown away by how delicious this was. The only thing I did differently was add a little cornstarch slurry to the pot at the end to help thicken the sauce.

Overall a good recipe. I made the lamb shanks with one cup of wine. Seasoned with Salt and pepper, seared them first. No broth. Add Fire roasted tomatoes. Tomato paste. Herbs. Lots of fresh garlic. Onions. Dried apricots. No broth. Carrots. Water. Cooked on a pressure cooker for one hour. Added the carrots and dried apricots. Cooked an additional half hour. Topped off with fresh parsley. They were tender and delicious. Served with orzo risotto.
Great recipe. Broth is delicious.
I didn’t have any Tyme but it was delicious anyway

I only had 4 lamb shanks so I adjusted the ingredient amounts in proportion. Otherwise, I followed the recipe as written. The lamb was very tender and flavorful. I served with polenta, but had a lot of sauce leftover. This could have been cook's error when reducing sauce though. Very good overall and will make again.
I made the recipe as is and it was absolutely amazing! I took the time to slowly reduce the sauce for about an hour after taking the lamb out. It became thick and incredible.

Fantastic recipe! Really easy to modify too. For example, I found using 1/4 the bottle of wine and then drinking the rest was a great value add. Also added some cinnamon, lemon zest, black vinegar, and exclusively used beef broth (and significantly less than called for). It turned out amazing!

Great recipe. Love the flavour. I strained some of the liquid and boiled it down for a few minutes and then thickened it with a cornstarch slurry. The sauce becomes a gravy consistency and pour over the lamb and mash potatoes. Also used on pasta.

I had to substitute fresh tomatoes for the canned, and didn’t have any thyme, but, it turned out spectacular nonetheless. The fresh tomatoes made the sauce almost sweet—I don’t think I will go back to canned. Missed the thyme, though...

I made this with two smaller shanks in a cast iron Dutch oven, and reducing the recipe by 2/3rds. I also added celery to increase the vegetable portion, and used a can of diced tomatoes, as well as dried thyme and rosemary, since that’s what I had on hand. 

I browned the shanks in the Dutch oven on the stovetop, then removed them and cooked the vegetables as per the recipe. Then I added in the tomatoes and liquids, substituting vegetable stock for beef stock, because that’s what I had in the pantry. I did use chicken stock and red wine.

I returned the shanks to the pot, submerging them and stirred in a 1/4 cup of water to completely cover. I brought everything to a boil, then put the cover on and placed the Dutch oven into my main oven at 400 degrees for 30 minutes, then reducing the temperature to 350 for another 90 minutes.

Finally, I removed the cover and let it all simmer for another 20 minutes in my main oven. It was fall-off-the-bone, and the sauce was perfect for pouring over the shank on the plate. Absolutely delicious! I will make this again. Thanks to the original author for posting this recipe!

I used significantly less wine (about 1 cup) and only one 1.5 lb. lamb shank, and it was still delicious, served over egg noodles and with baguette for dipping in the sauce. One lamb shank was almost enough for my family of 4. I saved the flavorful stock and will use it tonight to make risotto. Will use a bit more wine next time!
A lot of work, but worth every minute of it! It was delicious!

I AM NEW TO LAMB AND I LOVE IT. THE ROSEMARY LAMB SHANK WAS VERY SIMPLE TO MAKE. AND DELICIOUS. THE ONLY CHANGE THAT I DID WAS ADD 2 TSP. OF CHICKEN FLAVOR BOUILLON THAT HELPED TONE DOWN THE BITTERNESS FROM THE RED WINE AND I COOKED IT IN A CAST IRON DUTCH POT WHICH ONLY TOOK 90 MINUTES TO COOK.
Strain the gravy before serving.
My family loved this. I’ll definitely make it again.
Cooked it for my first time today. It was amazing! We are definitely buying more lamp to cook soon.

I had a number of problems with this recipe.

Firstly, the medium high heat for the initial browning of the shanks was too high. There was lots of spiting and the shanks stuck to the pan. Then "Medium low"was too high for simmering.

In the end, things turned out ok but the amount of time and effort wasn't worth the final result. I won't be making this again. 

Grilled lamb chops taste much better for a lot less effort.

OMG!!! This is the BEST!!! I had fresh lamb from the farm, and used fresh veggies from the farm too. Also used a sweet red table wine from a vineyard just south of us. This was amazing, and so easy to make.
This was savory and delicious! My only change, I only had one half of a lamb leg! Thank you for this one! I will make this again!
Add stew meat and this is an EXCELLENT recipe for ease and really tasty different take on lamb!
The best lamb I have ever made. This recipe is awesome. I did it with (8) lamb chops and followed the recipe as stated. My husband and I loved it.
For me, you can never go wrong with lamb. Next time I’ll add more veggies and thicken the sauce more.
Absolutely superb...
yummy!
Delicious, family favorite
Simple and easy to make, delicious!!
I didn't have any red wine but everything else was the same. It was very tender and full of flavor.
I had to cut the recipe by two thirds for just two people but it was excellent!
I made it for a holiday meal and it certainly did impress!
I used white wine instead of red & added sweet potato chunks as had both of these available. So good!!

I read through all the reviews, so adjusted as follows: I cooked it the day before I was serving it. I used about half the wine and half the tomatoes, and added a few tablespoons of tomato paste. After browning the meat and sauteeing the veggies etc. I cooked it in the oven at 350 for 2 hours, then cooled and put in the fridge overnight. The next day I reheated it in the oven at 200 degrees for about an hour before serving. I still needed to reduce the sauce somewhat (I added some cornstarch to thicken at the end). It was fantastic, rave reviews by all!
This had so much going on. The wine, tomatoes and beef broth overpowered the lamb, which was disappointing to me.

Followed the directions besides
chicken broth for condensed chicken broth
Lemon thyme for thyme 
Added a few tbs of salt
Fresh hopped parsley for the top

Mashed potatoes 
Garlic, butter, salt &pepper,and chicken broth
Easy to make, flavor was fabulous!

I have made this several times. The only way I deviate from the original recipe is that after I brown the shanks, I put them in my slower cooker. I then saute the veggies, add the liquids and herbs and pour that over the shanks. Cook on high for 4 hours, on low for 7. When they’re done, I remove the shanks to an ovenproof casserole dish. I strain the liquid into a saucepan. I gently boil the liquid until reduced by about a third. I thicken it with a mixture of cornstarch and water and pour over the shanks. You could serve it then but I always cover and refrigerate, reheat the next day. It is so much better the next day. I often halve the recipe, turns out just as well.
I added a touch of garlic to the mashed potatoes, and added kale at the very end for some texture and color. DeLISH!!!
Simple yet tasty lamb shanks!

I bought two lamb shanks from our local butcher and had about 3 lb. total. Clearly six shanks would have been way too much. Other than that, I did exactly what the recipe specified. The meat was fall-off-the-bone done after about 90 minutes. I used some of the liquid mixed with corn starch to thicken it. Served over extra-wide egg noodles, because that is what we had on hand.
I followed the recipe exactly but I added small potatoes. I braised it in a skillet then transferred it to the crock pot and cooked it on high for 4 hours .
So tasty! Used dried Italian spice Mx because my rosemary was under a foot of snow. Also simmered for 2.5 hours instead of 2. Pulled the meat off the bone and added to the finished sauce. Delicious!
Made per recipe. Not jazzed...husband and daughter liked it but I thought it lacked flavor. Won’t make it again.
Delicious! Follow the directions and it came out perfectly.
This is absolutely delicious! The lamb fell off the bone and the sauce was amazing! Thank you!

Add some celery along with the onions and carrots, . Put all the veggies in a food processor first. (Before cooking)You may need to add a bit if olive oil. Make it into a "paste" like substance.
It thickens the liquid and makes for a better presentation when serving.
Make sure to serve it with a nice bottle of wine. Pinot Noir is my choice with lamb.

I am in the process of making this. I purchased a pkg of 5 shanks from a wholesaler and they were huge! I have the second largest LeCruset oval Dutch oven and they barely fit. Two are peaking above the liquid line. Maybe ones purchased at a box grocery store are smaller IDK. So my point is you will need a really large pot.
No, and yes I’ll make it again.

I used about 2.5 lbs. of lamb shanks so I cut down on all of liquids. For the tomatoes I used 1 14.5oz can of whole cherry tomatoes and they worked out great for texture and taste. I served this dish over garlicked whipped potatoes. Delicious
I have made this recipe 3x now. Very tasty!
We raise lamb, and shank is my favorite lamb dish. I smoked the shanks for about 3 hours to give a little more depth of flavor. Easy to make, will do again for sure.
I added portabella mushrooms. It made it rich and flavorful. Meat fell off the bone!

My husband and his brother loved this recipe. All they could do is talk about how delicious this was. I followed the recipe except for 2 items I added celery and I just used beef broth instead of chicken chicken stock. I will be making this again!
There's too much liquid in this recipe by half. In fact, if you add it all up it's just shy of 2 liters worth of liquid. There's no way to reduce that even in 2 hours. Otherwise good.
LOVE IT! And making it was easier than I thought! THANK YOU
Delicious recipe , my husband loved , the flavor was great.
This is legit! Followed the recipe as is except mine took about 2.5 hours before I took lid off for the last 20 minutes. It was SO good!! Thank you I will def make this again, everyone loved it!
Turned out delicious. Definitely make it again
AWESome. Will definitely make I again again.

Made this for dinner last evening. Followed the recipe but condensed the measurements for 3. Big hit, hubby loved it. He has always stated that he didn't enjoy lamb. If I could give it more than 5 stars, I would.
Turned out amazing. I decided to follow the recipe as written and like some said there was a lot of sauce left over but I was fine that. I will definitely make this again

I gave this recipe a try and was not disappointed! It was easy to put together and had great flavor. I used a can of diced tomatoes because I did not have whole ones. The shanks came out tender, flavorful, and fall-off-the-bone perfect! My house smelled heavenly while they were cooking.

Our friend who requested lamb shanks for Easter, took a bite, sat there paralyzed saying nothing. His daughter said, “ Woah, this is goood!” End of story. Topped onto roasted garlic mashed potatoes. omg
This recipe was easy and absolutely fabulous. The lamb was tender and nearly falling off the bone. A winner!
yummy! Will make again
Super easy and tasty. I used carrots and parsnips because that's what I had. Will def make again. Great option for winter entertaining.
Great, used a Pinot Noir /zinfandel 50/50 wine. Came out great. Use all fresh ingredients.

Great recipe!!! The only changes I made were to use dried herbs instead of fresh and turkey bone broth instead of chicken broth, because that is what I had. Hubby LOVED it, as did I. We served it over Japanese rice, as that is his favorite starch. Definitely worth doing again, in spite of the cost of lamb shanks. Thank you for a stand-out, "rib-sticking" recipe!!!
Excellent recipe. Made this in a 5.2 qt dutch oven. Didn't change a thing. Very powerful flavors, not for the lighthearted or finicky eater. Lamb shanks are gamier than other cuts of lamb.

I followed the directions exactly. It was such an awesome meal. I made this for 6 people who were blown away. 

The sauce went really well with barley in which soaked up the sauce. 

Yes I would make this again, this is on our menu! I have a photo on my profile.
Great! I served it on mashed cauliflower.

I did the shanks in the oven at 320 for 2 hours covered and 30 minutes with the cover off. I doubled the reduction time at a bit more than a simmer just to thicken it up a bit. It's a fantastic recipe. I've noticed a few other that thought it fell a bit flat which confuses me. I wonder if they under-seasoned and under-browned the shanks prior to the braise. I'd also wonder what wine they used. Be generous with the seasoning and the sear and use wine you'd happily drink.

We really loved this dish! I'm glad my husband coaxed me into following the recipe as written. I was worried that so much wine would make it cloyingly icky-rich, which happened once when I made coq au vin... But no! The sauce is savory & just right. Bonus...there's a lot of it, much more than we'll use with the shanks. I plan to add it to an upcoming lamb stew, because YUM!
Excellent recipe followed it as written and will make it again.
Delicious recipe! I followed other suggestions of only half a bottle of red wine, doubled carrots, added parsnips and potatoes. Flavorful and with plenty of sauce to mop up with crusty bread. Yum!

As written, this recipe is just ok. However, it is a very flavorful if you reduce the sauce and add some tomato paste. I added celery to the veg mixture too. After the initial 2 hours of cooking, I took the carrots out (as many as I could) along with the shanks. Keep them warm in a low temp oven. I reduced the sauce for about 20-30 mins. Add the lamb and the carrots back in and simmer so the meat absorbs the reduced sauce. Served over very thin pappardelle (Cipriani). Excellent with modifications!

As written, this recipe is just ok. However, it is a very flavorful if you reduce the sauce and add some tomato paste. I added celery to the veg mixture too. After the initial 2 hours of cooking, I took the carrots out (as many as I could) along with the shanks. Keep them warm in a low temp oven. I reduced the sauce for about 20-30 mins. Add the lamb and the carrots back in and simmer so the meat absorbs the reduced sauce. Served over very thin pappardelle (Cipriani). Excellent with modifications!
Loved it!
Loved it!
Will absolutely make again and again.

My husband saw something about Lamb Shanks on TV and decided we should try them. We loved them!! The sauce is delicious and even if we don't make the full recipe with the Shanks, we still make the full recipe for the sauce because it's so good!! My husband made them twice and I'm cooking them myself for the first time!!

This was fabulous. It was definitely a restaurant quality meal. I prepped mid-afternoon and then let it simmer. Guests arrived and all I had to do was reduce and make sides. I served polenta & green beans. I did add 1 small can of tomato paste to help thicken based on reviews of a lot of liquid. Taking the time to reduce is important!
Excellent recipe .... one of the best meals I’ve cooked
This dish tasted fantastic. It definitely tasted as though it were harder to make than it was! Recipe is easy to follow. Two thumbs up.
Excellent meal. Easy to make. Company and my husband all loved it. When I make it next time I will use less liquid. It was far too much.

I made this for family dinner. I followed the recipe and served mashed potatoes and a salad. I used a Cabernet for the wine. Everyone loved it! There were no leftovers except some sauce which I am going to use as s base for a stew.

I made these and they were a knock out. I prepared according to the recipe except at the very end, as suggested by another reviewer, I added a corn starch slurry to tighten up the gravy. I served them with mashed potatoes but polenta would be good or egg noodles or rice. I will do polenta next time. Even my wife and older son who were a little off lamb raved about them.
Delicious just as is. The only change we made was add a pinch of cayenne pepper. We will definitely make this one again. Not boring at all!
What a treat! My husband and I love this recipe! I serve it with garlic mashed potatoes and green beans. I skip the wine and it comes out wonderfully.
This was absolutely delicious, a recipe I am doing again. I added more garlic to the recipe and it was so easy!

This was SO good! We felt like we had a gourmet meal at home. All of the prep is done at the front end so while its braising you can get other things done. I cut the ingredients back a bit b/c I only used 4 lamb shanks. I followed as is except I used a little more garlic, added 1/2 can of tomato paste, and in addition to the herbs called for, put in two sprigs of thyme and pulled them out before reducing. Because I use reduced sodium stock, I added a little salt and pepper and then reduced at a full boil for just shy of 20 min. The reduction was absolutely delicious! Thank you for a wonderful & elegant recipe!

This was fantastic. I had fewer shanks and tried to cut down the sauce but I had a lot left over. Froze the sauce but have no idea what I will do with it. After reading another critique I forgot to add that I did thicken the sauce with a little cornstarch as it was too watery.

Our new "go to" lamb recipe. Followed recipe mostly. After browning lamb and veggies, I marinated all for a day. Substituted veggie stock for chicken. Cooked it 2.5 hours at 350 the next day, then refrigerated another night. Final day cooked another hour or so until all lamb fell off shanks. Added a bit more red wine and seasonings to reduction sauce. The planned overs barely made it to noon the next day!
Great dish. My family loves it. Not to difficult to make. Meat was literally falling off the bone. Everything was bursting with flavor. We put it over rice instead of potatoes.
Great,I would make it again.
Very good. I used lamb chops. Made this for some friends the other night. My wife hates lamb. I just said i was making a "chop" dish. Her and one of our friends didn't believe it was lamb.
Very good. I used lamb chops. Made this for some friends the other night. My wife hates lamb. I just said i was making a "chop" dish. Her and one of our friends didn't believe it was lamb.

Fabulous. I've made this dish so many times and never been disappointed. I usually reduce the amount of wine called for, and I like to use a good Zinfandel, but I've even used ale. I grind my salt, red pepper flakes, dried rosemary, and some dried oregano and add this to the onions and garlic when I sauté them. I use my own homemade bone broth (usually made from chicken and turkey) for both the chicken and beef broth. Then I add fresh bay leaf and thyme to the Dutch oven before I cover and braise in the oven. I never have to reduce the sauce if I use my Dutch oven and cook in the oven. Our favourite way to eat this is with a creamy garlic risotto but we also love it with mashed potatoes. It is our favourite fancy dish and what my husband always requests on his birthday or around Christmas.

Made this dish for Christmas dinner and everyone loved it. The only things I did differently was use 2 cans of beef broth and no chicken, added some tomato paste and made a bundle of fresh rosemary and thyme instead of chopping it. Will be making this again the next time I find a good deal on lambshanks. Delicious.
Amazing. The only change I made was to purée the tomatos, as I don't like chunks of tomatos. My 10 year old daughter said it's the best recipe we've ever found! Perfect!
